title: It’s a Cacophony Spring! — “Tales of the San Francisco Cacophony Society” book release events in May 2013
author: Summer Burkes
content:
City Lights Bookstore SF, where modern American literature was born, announces:

Tales of the San Francisco Cacophony Society LAUNCH PARTY !
Thursday, May 16, 2013, 7:00 P.M., City Lights Boosktore, San Francisco, California

“An evening of irreverent antics

with Kevin Evans, Carrie Galbraith, John Law and friends

celebrating the release of

Tales of the San Francisco Cacophony Society
Edited by Kevin Evans, Carrie Galbraith and John Law

published by Last Gasp Books

Come one, come all…..at your own risk.

A template for pranksters, artists, adventurers and anyone interested in rampant creativity, Tales of the San Francisco Cacophony Society is the history of the most influential underground cabal you’ve never heard of. Rising from the ashes of the mysterious and legendary Suicide Club, the Cacophony Society, at its zenith, hosted chapters in over a dozen major cities, and influenced much of what was once called the underground. The Cacophony Society’s epic exploits radically changed the way people live and play in the world. The group inspired Chuck Palahniuk’s Fight Club and Burning Man and helped start pop culture trends including flash mobs, urban exploration, and culture jamming.”

What has been said about Tales of the San Francisco Cacophony Society:

Just to give y’all dear readers an idea of the mayhem … Here’s the trailer to Jon Alloway’s long-awaited and recently-premiered Cacophony Society documentary Into the Zone: The Story of the Cacophony Society —

“Into the Zone – The Story of the Cacophony Society” trailer – a film by Jon Alloway

Then … Then! May 31, 2013, there’s kind of the official show, which is NOT the official show. Starring the YES MEN!!! We’ll let the esteemed ringmonster explain it — Chicken John, one of Cacophony’s highest-ranked showmen:

Don’t live in SF? … Cacophony’s going on the road afterwards! … From Carrie Galbraith‘s page:

Disclosure: This writer, Summer Burkes, has three or four pieces in the book, originally published in the heady days of arts journalism and editorship at the San Francisco Bay Guardian, an independently-owned free weekly paper in San Francisco (which is now owned by a corporate megalith, and someone in the I.T. department deleted all the “old” SFBG articles and my “Dilettante” columns from the Internets. *sigh*) … I’ll be reading — ulp, first book reading ever — at City Lights, and maybe other places too.

Word on the street is that on May 16 at City Lights in SF, they’ll be closing off Kerouac Alley so the overflow crowd can watch the party via huge projectors on the walls while they drink at Vesuvio’s and raise a ruckus for the ghosts of the mighty Beat poets who blazed the trail before us. ::shivers::

Hope to see y’all there! Invite each and every one of your friends who still believe the horribly streamlined LLC origin story that Larry Harvey somehow drove all the trucks and moved all the things and invented Burning Man all by himself! … And even if you live elsewhere or otherwise can’t make the events, you can pre-order some books for you and your flaming loved ones, straight from the hallowed halls of Last Gasp.
